journal-meta.journal-title: Interpretation: A Journal of Bible and Theology

body.p: Erhard S. Gerstenberger has been a professor of Old Testament in Germany, Brazil, and the U.S. He retired from Marburg University as Professor Emeritus. Gerstenberger is the author or editor of 15 books and has written over 100 articles on Old Testament theology, form criticism, feminist criticism, and liberation theology. He has also worked as a parish minister, doing both preaching and adult education. His interests include travel and the study of ancient Near Eastern literature and languages, especially Sumerian.

Carleen Mandolfo is Associate Professor of Hebrew Bible at Claremont School of Theology. She received her Ph.D. from Emory University. Mandolfo specializes in biblical lament literature, feminist criticism, and dialogic theology. She has written/edited a number of books, articles, and entries on these topics, including Daughter Zion Talks Back to the Prophets: A Dialogic Theology of the Book of Lamentations (Society of Biblical Literature, 2007). Her other interests include Bible and film, and post-Holocaust theological hermeneutics, both areas in which she has taught extensively.

Beau Harris is a Ph.D. student in Hebrew Bible at Claremont School of Theology. He received a M.Div. from Vanderbilt Divinity School in 2010. Harris’ primary research interests include: Wisdom and lament literature of the Hebrew Bible and ancient Near East; postcolonial, post-Shoah, and feminist hermeneutics; and utilizing popular media in biblical and theological pedagogy. He is currently Adjunct Professor of Biblical Studies at Azusa Pacific University.

Dianne Bergant, CSA is the Carroll Stuhlmueller, CP, Distinguished Professor of Old Testament Studies at Catholic Theological Union. She earned a Ph.D. in Biblical Literature and Languages from St. Louis University. Bergant’s major area of teaching is the Wisdom Literature of ancient Israel. Her current interests lie in the fields of interpretation and biblical theology, especially in the areas of feminism, peace and justice, and ecology. She has written commentaries on various biblical books, as well as on the lectionary readings for the Sundays of the liturgical year. Bergant’s two-volume commentary on Psalms (Liturgical Press) is expected to appear in the spring of 2013.

Nancy C. Lee is Professor of Hebrew Bible and Niebuhr Distinguished Chair at Elmhurst College in Chicago. Her research and teaching interests include Hebrew poetry, biblical women prophets, justice in religion and society, and indigenous cultural traditions. Lee was a Fulbright fellow to Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina and co-leads a course to South Africa, where she is Visiting Extraordinary Professor at the University of Stellenbosch. A co-founder of the Society of Biblical Literature Lament group, she has edited or authored four books related to biblical lament, including Lyrics of Lament: From Tragedy to Transformation (Fortress, 2010). Lee earned her Ph.D. from Union Presbyterian Seminary and is an ordained minister.

Kandy Queen-Sutherland (Ph.D., Southern Baptist Theological Seminary) is the Sam R. Marks Professor of Religion at Stetson University. Her teaching interests focus on topics of social justice in the interplay of religion with race, gender, and class issues. She also taught for eight years on an international theological faculty in Rüschlikon, Switzerland. Queen-Sutherland is Old Testament Editor for Smyth & Helwys Bible Commentary, and the author of Ruth, Esther, Song of Songs & Lamentations in that series (forthcoming). She is an ordained Baptist minister and has written numerous articles on preaching biblical texts.
